articles.headline: Republicans, Closing In on Final Tax Bill, Aim for a Vote Next Week
articles.snippet: In a frenzy of last-minute negotiations, Republicans drew closer to a 21 percent corporate tax rate and a top individual rate of 37 percent.
articles.abstract: In a frenzy of last-minute negotiations, Republicans drew closer to a 21 percent corporate tax rate and a top individual rate of 37 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican lawmakers, scrambling to reach agreement on a final tax bill that they hope to pass next week, are coalescing around a plan that would slightly raise the proposed corporate tax rate, lower the top rate on the richest Americans and scale back the existing mortgage interest deduction.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: ‘Fake News,’ Trump’s Obsession, Is Now a Cudgel for Strongmen
articles.snippet: Leaders who don’t like to be criticized or investigated have embraced the term. Scholars fear that it further erodes trust in democracy.
articles.abstract: Leaders who don’t like to be criticized or investigated have embraced the term. Scholars fear that it further erodes trust in democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Trump routinely invokes the phrase “fake news” as a rhetorical tool to undermine opponents, rally his political base and try to discredit a mainstream American media that is aggressively investigating his presidency.

articles.headline: Quakes and Fires? It’s the Cost of Living That Californians Can’t Stomach
articles.snippet: For many Californians, natural disasters are a moment to take stock and rethink the dream. But in the end, it almost always comes down to cost.
articles.abstract: For many Californians, natural disasters are a moment to take stock and rethink the dream. But in the end, it almost always comes down to cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Russel Lee and his wife spent the past few years going online to do the depressing math of how much less housing costs pretty much everywhere that isn’t California. They looked at Idaho, Arizona, North Carolina and Kentucky, but Mr. Lee, who was born in San Francisco and has lived in the Bay Area his entire life, could never quite make the move. Then the fires came.

articles.headline: Disney’s Deal for 21st Century Fox Is Said to Be Close
articles.snippet: The $60 billion-plus acquisition would give Disney control of most of Rupert Murdoch’s movie and TV empire, and give a serious boost to the company’s streaming ambitions.
articles.abstract: The $60 billion-plus acquisition would give Disney control of most of Rupert Murdoch’s movie and TV empire, and give a serious boost to the company’s streaming ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company was poised to complete a once-unthinkable deal to swallow most of Rupert Murdoch’s movie and television empire, a $60 billion-plus acquisition that would supercharge Disney’s global streaming-service ambitions, threaten to undercut Silicon Valley’s entertainment aspirations and most likely prompt further consolidation in Hollywood.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Once a Long Shot, Democrat Doug Jones Wins Alabama Senate Race
articles.snippet: Doug Jones, a former prosecutor, defeated scandal-scarred Roy S. Moore for the Senate seat once held by Attorney General Jeff Sessions.
articles.abstract: Doug Jones, a former prosecutor, defeated scandal-scarred Roy S. Moore for the Senate seat once held by Attorney General Jeff Sessions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Doug Jones, a Democratic former prosecutor who mounted a seemingly quixotic Senate campaign in the face of Republican dominance here, defeated his scandal-scarred opponent, Roy S. Moore, after a brutal campaign marked by accusations of sexual abuse and child molestation against the Republican.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: For Trump, a Moment of Defeat but Maybe Not Recalibration
articles.snippet: President Trump, never one to accept blame, said the Democratic upset in Alabama proved he was right all along, and he gave little indication that he would shift course.
articles.abstract: President Trump, never one to accept blame, said the Democratic upset in Alabama proved he was right all along, and he gave little indication that he would shift course.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump does not readily admit defeat. Knocked to the mat in Alabama with the stunning loss of a Senate seat, he got right back up on Wednesday and defiantly claimed that he had known his candidate would lose all along. He may have been humbled by voters, but Mr. Trump does not exactly do humble.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: How 2017 Became a Turning Point for Tech Giants
articles.snippet: For the first time, big tech companies began to accept responsibility in 2017 for how their platforms affect the world. The scope of that change remains unclear.
articles.abstract: For the first time, big tech companies began to accept responsibility in 2017 for how their platforms affect the world. The scope of that change remains unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was a terrible year for the tech industry.

articles.headline: Fed Predicts Modest Economic Growth From Tax Cut
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve continued to slowly increase interest rates, and it said the tax bill was unlikely to increase its pace of doing so.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve continued to slowly increase interest rates, and it said the tax bill was unlikely to increase its pace of doing so.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, buoyed by a steadily strengthening economy, raised interest rates on Wednesday for a fifth time since the financial crisis and predicted that a proposed tax cut moving through Congress would modestly increase economic growth for the next few years without stoking inflation.

articles.headline: Black Voters in Alabama Pushed Back Against the Past
articles.snippet: Turned off by Roy S. Moore, Stephen K. Bannon and President Trump, African-Americans turned out at levels that ensured victory for the Democratic Senate candidate.
articles.abstract: Turned off by Roy S. Moore, Stephen K. Bannon and President Trump, African-Americans turned out at levels that ensured victory for the Democratic Senate candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — The word traveled, urgently and insistently, along the informal networks of black friends, black family and black co-workers: Vote.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Campbell Robertson
